net.objectof.corc

Interface Handler<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The Type of object processed through the Handler.
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    IAsyncForwarder, ICollectingRequest, IExceptionHandler, IForwarder, IHandler, IMsgAdaptor, IMsgSender, IPing, IRateLimiter, IRegister, IRepoHandler, IRequest, IRequestor, IResponder, IResponseHandler, IResponseRequest, IRouter, IScript, IService, IStep, IStreamAdaptor, IStreamingRequest, IUtilHandler, IWebAdaptor, IWebHandler, IWebHandler, IWebPing, IWebRequest, IWebServiceRouter, TestApp, TestWebServiceHandler

    public interface Handler<T>
    A Handler provides the interface for execution of a Request Action. Multiple Handlers can be chained, aggregated, and composed to create a composite orchestrated service pipeline.

    A Handler differs from a Service in that there is no return value from its execute() interface therefore enabling non-blocking asynchronous execution of actions. Whether or not the Handler executes asynchronously or not is determined by implementations based on specific (functional) requirements and system non-functional requirements and topology. For example a given Handler may be required to execute synchronously when the action must be completed prior to performing the next step due to functional (business) constraints.

    In general, a Handler instance handles multiple actions in its lifetime therefore implementations must be thread-safe and the design contract is for per-action state to be put on the Object argument, possibly by wrapping the action object within a user-defined envelope/wrapper. Extensions to the Action interface are supported for extension of overall action state for a given service.

    The expected pattern for implementation is a concrete Handler will be wired through a dependency injection mechanism.

    Author:
    jdh

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void execute(Action aAction, T aObject)
      Executes an Action on a request chain.
      Interface<T> getType() 

    • Method Detail

      • execute

        void execute(Action aAction,
             T aObject)
        Executes an Action on a request chain. There is no return value, the Handler forwards the result action to the next Handler on the request chain. This design promotes Handlers being able to determine whether the execution path is synchronous or asynchronous.
        Parameters:
        aAction - The Action to perform.
        aObject - The object being processed by this Handler.

      • getType

        Interface<T> getType()
